properties.name: <![CDATA[Bus Stop]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[Regular and inexpensive buses from Oxford - http://city.oxfordbus.co.uk/timetables-fares/cityx3-cityx13-city13#timetable]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[St Helen's Wharf]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[The River Thames and St Helen's Wharf - traditional centre of Abingdon's trade.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[The River Thames and St Helen's Wharf - traditional centre of Abingdon's trade.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[St Helens Church]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[The second widest church in Britain, due to incremental extensions by townsfolk. With three rows of Almshouses in its churchyard. And site of a famous highly decorative ancient cross (destroyed in the Civil War) which represented indpendence of the town to the Abbey. Today, St. Helens is not always open, so contact the Church Office before setting out if you want to be sure of access - 01235 520144 - or administrator@sthelens-abingdon.org.uk]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[The second widest church in Britain, due to incremental extensions by townsfolk. With three rows of Almshouses in its churchyard. And site of a famous highly decorative ancient cross (destroyed in the Civil War) which represented indpendence of the town to the Abbey. Today, St. Helens is not always open, so contact the Church Office before setting out if you want to be sure of access - 01235 520144 - or administrator@sthelens-abingdon.org.uk]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[St Helens Almshouses]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[The only graveyard in Britain to be filled with Almshouses.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[The only graveyard in Britain to be filled with Almshouses.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[County Hall]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Britain's most impressive town-hall, from whose rooftop comes Abingdon's curious but pleasant public bun-throwing tradition, held by the council to celebrate great historic occasions.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[Britain's most impressive town-hall, from whose rooftop comes Abingdon's curious but pleasant public bun-throwing tradition, held by the council to celebrate great historic occasions.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[St Nicolas Church]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[First of the surviving Abbey buildings. Built set into the Abbey walls - as much to keep the townsfolk out as to let them in...]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[First of the surviving Abbey buildings. Built set into the Abbey walls - as much to keep the townsfolk out as to let them in...]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[The Abbey Gatehouse]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[The next survivor of the once great Abingdon Abbey. Local legend claims that those in the know hold their breath when passing through this gate, "so gargoyles can't steal your breath".]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[The next survivor of the once great Abingdon Abbey. Local legend claims that those in the know hold their breath when passing through this gate, "so gargoyles can't steal your breath".]]>

properties.desc: <![CDATA[Original Abbey building]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Barrow Hills]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Bronze Age burial mounds, in two long alleyways of mounds. Now almost entirely flattened.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[Bronze Age burial mounds, in two long alleyways of mounds. Now almost entirely flattened.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[St James the Great, Radley]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[A church whose roof is supported by wooden pillars, after the 13th Century abbot had a dream telling hom to do so - despite the rest of the building being stone. Such was the faith in action of the Medieval Church - its buildings were literally made of dreams! https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radley]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[A church whose roof is supported by wooden pillars, after the 13th Century abbot had a dream telling hom to do so - despite the rest of the building being stone. Such was the faith in action of the Medieval Church - its buildings were literally made of dreams! https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radley]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[St Leonard's Church, Sunningwell]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Jarn Mound]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Built by hand by Arthur Evans to preserve the famed view of Oxford' dreaming spires, under threat by private development and garden shrubberies...]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[Built by hand by Arthur Evans to preserve the famed view of Oxford' dreaming spires, under threat by private development and garden shrubberies...]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[St Lawrence Church, South Hinksey]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[14th Century and 19th Century blend of a Church. Patron saint is Lawrence: When his bishop, Sixtus, was denounced to the hostile pagan authorities, Laurence was put in charge of the church’s valuables, which he in turn entrusted to the poor of his congregation. Finally arrested, and charged to disclose the whereabouts of the church assets, Laurence showed the authorities the poor and sick of the church, saying, ‘Behold, here are the treasures of Christ’s Church’. Laurence was thus martyred for his refusal to comply by being roasted on a bed of hot iron bars.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[14th Century and 19th Century blend of a Church. Patron saint is Lawrence: When his bishop, Sixtus, was denounced to the hostile pagan authorities, Laurence was put in charge of the church’s valuables, which he in turn entrusted to the poor of his congregation. Finally arrested, and charged to disclose the whereabouts of the church assets, Laurence showed the authorities the poor and sick of the church, saying, ‘Behold, here are the treasures of Christ’s Church’. Laurence was thus martyred for his refusal to comply by being roasted on a bed of hot iron bars.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Tom Tower]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Gatehouse to Christ Church College and Cathedral. Tower holds the biggest bell in Oxford.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[Gatehouse to Christ Church College and Cathedral. Tower holds the biggest bell in Oxford.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Christ church Cathedral, Oxford]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Site of the shrine of Saint Frithuswith, patron of Oxford and the University. She resisted the forced romance of Algar, whom God made fall from his horse (and die) while chasing Frithuswith. Later, she prays for water to sustain nuns in Binsey, and it rises from the ground. Her shrine was St Frithuswith's Priory, which became Christ Church Cathedral. A chapel is dedicated to her today, and an Edward Burnes-Jones stained glass window represents her beautifully. For Opening times, see: http://goo.gl/2TnhEj -  To learn what time the free Choral Evensong service takes place, see the Music List: http://goo.gl/kq73UP]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[Site of the shrine of Saint Frithuswith, patron of Oxford and the University. She resisted the forced romance of Algar, whom God made fall from his horse (and die) while chasing Frithuswith. Later, she prays for water to sustain nuns in Binsey, and it rises from the ground. Her shrine was St Frithuswith's Priory, which became Christ Church Cathedral. A chapel is dedicated to her today, and an Edward Burnes-Jones stained glass window represents her beautifully. For Opening times, see: http://goo.gl/2TnhEj -  To learn what time the free Choral Evensong service takes place, see the Music List: http://goo.gl/kq73UP]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Abingdon Abbey to Christ Church Cathedral, Oxford - Over Boars Hill (12 miles)_Abingdon Abbey to Christ Church Cathedral, Oxford - Over Boars Hill]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[A 12 mile 1-day pilgrimage route from Abingdon Abbey to Christ Church Cathedral, Oxford, via Boars Hill, retreat of many of Britain's great poets. Download a GPX file for the route here: ]]>
